No work life balance and director of HRL says she doesn't want to hear this phrase
Not given a lot of room for growth 
If you want change either socially or just try to make a process more smooth you will get push back as it is not "the Marshall way" (Campus wide issue)
Heavy focus on tradition (no matter how outdated) 
The whole "Sons and Daughters" of Marshall is sexist, transphobic, and has tones of racism.

review_title: Good...if you don't want to leave your comfort zone.
pros:
Many great fellow employees. Most genuinely care for the students that they serve. There are a few exceptions, but luckily a few have retired as of late. 

I feel that, especially for WV, diversity and inclusion are observed (or at least attempted to be observed) here. I don't think there's active discrimination of any sort - if anything, you probably run into a stray redneck here and there who doesn't know better. 

The students here are also great. Most of them are "what you see is what you get," not pretentious like where I did undergrad. 

The leave here is great - 24 days/year for unclassified staff, PLUS a roughly week and a a half Christmas break. 

Marshall is an easy place to settle in and get comfortable - it's like that old pair of shoes that you love.
cons:
Sooner or later you need "new shoes." Huntington is okay, depending on which part you're in. Some aren't bad, some are completely gross. You're also quite a drive from more major cities (Columbus, Cincinnati, Lexington, etc.) Huntington has a "good ol' boy" small town type of feel - I suppose that can be good or bad, depending upon how you look at it. Huntington definitely seems more like a small town the longer I'm here. 

 The University's pay scale also sucks (it's from 2001, according to a former coworker). Don't count on even getting cost of living raises, unless the WV teachers strike. There is little room for advancement as well. Good, young talent is passed over for outside hires, or someone incompetent on the inside who was decided would get the job even before the committee met.

Overall MU is a good place to kick off a career, but unless you can't stand the thought of leaving the area you're best off to eventually move on.

review_title: Low pay, but great atmosphere, colleagues, and students.
pros: Students are committed and hardworking.  Colleagues are professional, easy to get along with, and are supportive of each other.  The cost of living in the area is very reasonable, and there are just enough things to do on campus and in town to keep interested and busy.
cons: The pay has completely stagnated -- and it wasn't good before it stagnated.  On average, faculty at Marshall make 70% of the national average salaries for positions in the same area.  I took at huge pay cut to come to Marshall.  Compounding the difficult financial situation is the fact that the Huntington City Council recently passed at 1% income tax.  Between inflation, new taxes, and constant salaries (not even cost of living adjustments), it gets harder and harder to stay here each year.

pros:
I worked here while I was completing my undergraduate and graduate degree. It is nice to get paid for doing research as an undergraduate and I have worked for 6 months after I graduated.\

If you work with a good professor, then you will enjoy it.
cons:
The pay is low as you expect while you are working on your degree. They make it very difficult to get a raise. If your professor wants to give you a raise then they have to show that you are doing more work. 

Also, always get your payroll form in early because it will be sent back at least once. You could submit the same payroll form that they accepted six months ago, but they will say something is wrong this time.

review_title: Administration is running the place into the ground
pros: Cost of living is low in the Huntington area. The students at Marshall are generally hardworking and friendly.
cons:
Every semester faculty are required to revise their curriculum in some way - and it's never anything worthwhile or meaningful... just nonsense and buzz words.

Faculty salary has been stagnant for the past several years.  Meanwhile, the President has arranged for his salary to more than double.

The university is falling apart, financially - budget cuts, taking on loads of new debt, and overspending on non-essential projects (e.g., stadium skybox upgrades, new soccer field, unneeded engineering building, etc.).

review_title: Employees paid too little, not sufficiently trained
pros: As a graduate assistant, most of the people are kind, good-hearted people and fun to work with.
cons: Very demanding for a ridiculously low amount of money. Employees are paid on a 2001 pay scale and most seem untrained. They seem to be apathetic to improving themselves or working hard because the pay is so low and there is limited upward mobility. Tuition benefits were also on the 2001 pay scale, so graduate assistants still had to pay out-of-pocket. When tuition increased, the benefits remained the same.

job_title: Research Assistant I in Huntington, WV
pros: Good Work-Life balance. If you are from the surrounding area, there are not many other choices around. If you are the initiating type, there are chances to build a good resume.
cons: Isolated island in terms of scientific research. There are some good things happening but nowhere close to as in a metropolitan hub. Too relaxed to bring any positive change and compared to other ranked institutions. Learn what you have to and get out. Not for people who want a fast paced environment.

pros: People in West Virginia are very nice and getting free gear while working in sports.
cons: Constant change and disorganization, also staff is expected to do a TON with nothing while getting pulled in different directions with no clear objectives.  Plan to work CRAZY hours and I mean crazy with no nights or weekends to yourself. If you are in a relationship or married you will end having to choose between your significant other and the job. The AD was newer when I left so I am not sure how things have progressed but the Marketing and Ticket Sales Management were an absolute joke!

review_title: The wheels of bureaucracy turn slowly.
pros: I had a flexible work schedule and the ability to study what I wanted.
cons: I was employed for additional summer terms.  The paperwork was not done correctly and I was not paid until the end of the summer after jumping through many hoops.  It seemed that no one really cared if I received payment or not.

pros: Small campus. Easy to travel to and from. Great History. Great people to work with. They give you the tools you need for the job.
cons: Payscale. Most have to work multiple jobs to support their family. Upper management never knows what everyone is doing. No communication.
